text: Increased expression of cell surface <extra_id_0> IL-10R1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> on RA <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells

The functional receptor complex of <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> consists of two subunits , the primary ligand - binding component <extra_id_0> IL-10R1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and the accessory component <extra_id_0> type 2 IL-10R <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> [ 1 ] .
<extra_id_0> IL-10R1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression plays a critical role in cellular responses to <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> [ 29 ] .

To examine whether the resistance to <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> inhibition in RA <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells was due to limited receptor expression , the cell surface expression of <extra_id_0> IL-10R1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> on PB <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells from active RA patients and from healthy controls was determined by flow cytometric analysis .

As shown in Fig . 3a , 3b , the intensity of <extra_id_0> IL-10R1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression on <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells was significantly increased in RA patients compared with in healthy controls .

These results suggest that the intracellular signal transduction pathway of <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> may be impaired in <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells of active RA .
